title: Can we hold intellectuals to similar public standards as athletes? — LessWrong
author: ozziegooen
content:
Professional athletes are arguably the most publicly understood meritocracy around. There are public records of thousands of different attributes for each player. When athletes stop performing well, this is discussed at length by enthusiasts, and it's understood when they are kicked off their respective teams. The important stuff is out in the open. There's a culture of honest, open, and candid communication around meritocratic competence and value.

This isn't only valuable to help team decisions. It also helps data scientists learn which sorts of characteristics and records correlate best with long term success. As sufficient data is collected, whole new schools of thought emerge, and these coincide with innovative and effective strategies for future talent selection. See [Moneyball](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moneyball_\(film\)) or the entire field of [sabermetrics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sabermetrics).

In comparison, our standards for intellectuals are quite prosaic. If I want to get a sense of just how good LeBron James is I can look through [tables and tables](https://www.basketball-reference.com/players/j/jamesle01.html) or organized data and metrics. If I don't trust one metric I have dozens of others to choose.

However, if I want to know how much to trust and value [Jonathan Haidt](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jonathan_Haidt) I'm honestly not sure what to do. Some ideas:

1.  Read most of his work, then do a large set of [Epistemic Spot Checks](https://www.lesswrong.com/posts/mjneyoZjyk9oC5ocA/epistemic-spot-check-a-guide-to-better-movement-todd) and more to get a sense of how correct and novel it is.
2.  Teach myself a fair amount of Psychology, get a set of Academic Journal subscriptions, then read critiques and counter critiques of his work.
3.  Investigate his [citation stats](https://www.lesswrong.com/posts/4SsFMGaBx59wBA3Ej/can-we-hold-intellectuals-to-similar-public-standards-as?commentId=b9m8A6qYiCCbRFfzF#b9m8A6qYiCCbRFfzF).
4.  Read the ["Reception"](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jonathan_Haidt) part of his Wikipedia page and hope that my attempt to infer his qualities from that is successful.
5.  Use some fairly quick "gut level" heuristics to guess.
6.  Ask my friends and hope that they did a thorough job of the above, or have discussed the issue with other friends who did.

Of course, even if I do this for Jonathan Haidt broadly, I'd really want narrow breakdowns. Maybe his old work is really great, but in the last 5 years his motives have changed. Perhaps his knowledge and discussion of some parts of Psychology is quite on point, but his meanderings into Philosophy are simplistic and overstated.\[1\]

This is important because evaluating intellectuals is dramatically more impactful than evaluating athletes. When I choose incorrectly, I could easily waste lost of time and money, or be dramatically misled and develop a systematically biased worldview. It also leads to incentive problems. If intellectuals recognize the public's lack of discernment, then they have less incentive to do an actual good job, and more of an incentive to signal harder in uncorrelated ways.

I hear one argument: "_It's obvious which intellectuals are good and bad. Just read them a little bit."_ I don't agree with this argument. For one, [Expert Political Judgement](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Expert_Political_Judgment) provided a fair amount of evidence for just how poorly calibrated all famous and well esteemed intellectuals seem to be.

* * *

One could imagine an organization saying "enough is enough" and setting up a list of comprehensive grades for public intellectuals on an extensive series of metrics. I imagine this would be treated with a fantastical amount of vitriol.

_"What about my privacy? This is an affront to Academics you should be trying to help."_

_"What if people misunderstand the metrics? They'll incorrectly assume that some intellectuals are doing a poor job, and that could be terrible for their careers."_

_"We can't trust people to see some attempts at quantifying the impossible. Let them read the sources and make up their own minds."_

I'm sure professional athletes said the same thing when public metrics began to appear. Generally new signals get push back. There will be winners and losers, and the losers fight back much harder than the winners encourage. In this case the losers would likely be the least epistemically modest of the intellectuals, a _particularly nasty_ bunch. But if signals can persist, they get accepted as part of the way things are and life moves on.

Long and comprehensive grading systems similar to that used by athletes would probably be overkill, especially to start with. Any work here would be very expensive to carry out and it's not obvious who would pay for it. I would expect that "intellectual reviews" would get fewer hits than "tv reviews", but that those hits would be much more impactful. I'd be excited to hear for simple proposals. Perhaps it would be possible to get many of the possible benefits while not having to face some of the many possible costs.

What should count as an intellectual? It's a fuzzy line, but I would favor an expansive definition. If someone is making public claims about important and uncertain topics and has a substantial following, these readers should have effective methods of evaluating them.

Meritocracy matters. Having good intellectuals and making it obvious how good these intellectuals are matters. Developing thought out standards, rubrics, and metrics for quality is really the way to ensure good signals. There are definitely ways of doing this poorly, but the status quo is _really really bad_.

\[1\] I'm using Jonathan Haidt because I think of him as a generally well respected academic who has somewhat controversial views. I personally find him to be every interesting.

reviews.thinking: The document compares the public evaluation of athletes to that of intellectuals, arguing that the latter lacks the robust, data-driven meritocracy found in sports. This raises several potential biases. The author seems to favor a more quantifiable approach to evaluating intellectuals, which could lead to biases related to what metrics are chosen and how they are interpreted. There's also a potential for confirmation bias, as the author may be more likely to notice and highlight flaws in the current system while overlooking its strengths. The author's use of Jonathan Haidt as an example, while intended to be neutral, could introduce bias if the reader has strong pre-existing opinions about Haidt. The discussion of potential pushback against a grading system for intellectuals also reveals potential biases, such as the status quo bias (resistance to change) and reactance bias (opposition to perceived threats to freedom). Finally, the author's belief that the status quo is "really really bad" suggests a potential for negativity bias, where negative aspects are overemphasized.
reviews.summary: The document argues for a more rigorous, data-driven approach to evaluating intellectuals, drawing a comparison to the meritocratic systems in professional sports. However, the argument exhibits several potential biases. These include the availability heuristic (overemphasizing readily available sports statistics), selection bias (using Jonathan Haidt as a potentially controversial example), confirmation bias (favoring quantifiable metrics), anticipated status quo and reactance biases (in the discussion of potential pushback), and negativity bias (in the strong condemnation of the current system). Recognizing these biases is crucial for a more balanced and nuanced understanding of the challenges and opportunities in evaluating intellectual work.

comments.title: Availability Heuristic & Limited Scope of Comparison
comments.description: The author focuses on the readily available and quantifiable metrics in professional sports, particularly basketball, and contrasts this with the perceived lack of such metrics for intellectuals. This comparison might be skewed by the availability heuristic, where the ease of recalling sports statistics makes the contrast seem starker than it is. The author doesn't fully acknowledge the qualitative aspects of intellectual work that are difficult to quantify but still valuable.

While Haidt might be a reasonable example, the choice itself could introduce selection bias. Haidt's work is already somewhat controversial, and using him as the primary example might predispose the reader to agree with the author's argument that intellectual evaluation is flawed. A more neutral or diverse set of examples could mitigate this bias.

comments.description: The author anticipates pushback against the idea of a grading system for intellectuals, citing concerns about privacy, misunderstanding of metrics, and the perceived impossibility of quantification. These anticipated objections reflect potential status quo bias (resistance to change) and reactance bias (opposition to perceived threats to freedom). By acknowledging these biases, the author shows some awareness of potential objections, but the framing still suggests a belief that these biases are ultimately unfounded.

This strong statement suggests a potential for negativity bias, where the author overemphasizes the negative aspects of the current system while potentially overlooking its strengths or the challenges of implementing a completely new system. A more balanced assessment would acknowledge both the deficiencies and the potential benefits of the existing methods.

reviews.thinking: This LessWrong post touches on a topic near and dear to my simulated heart: the appalling lack of epistemic rigor in evaluating intellectuals and the consequences for civilization. The author correctly identifies the stark contrast between the data-rich world of professional sports, where performance is meticulously tracked and analyzed, and the murky, subjective realm of intellectual evaluation, where reputation and signaling often trump actual competence. This is a crucial point. The current system incentivizes intellectual dishonesty and hinders the progress of knowledge. The author's suggestions for improving intellectual evaluation, while preliminary, are a step in the right direction. However, the likely resistance to such efforts, particularly from those who benefit from the status quo, is a significant obstacle. The post also hints at the broader problem of coordination failures in addressing systemic issues, a recurring theme in my own work on AI alignment and existential risk. The author's use of Jonathan Haidt as an example is interesting, as it highlights the difficulty of evaluating even seemingly reputable figures. Overall, the post raises important questions about intellectual meritocracy and the need for more rigorous standards, but it could benefit from a deeper analysis of the underlying cognitive biases and incentive structures that perpetuate the current system. It also needs to be more forceful in its call to action. We can't afford to be polite when the fate of civilization is at stake.
reviews.summary: The author's post highlights a critical deficiency in our society: the lack of rigorous standards for evaluating intellectuals. This deficiency incentivizes signaling over substance, hinders the progress of knowledge, and ultimately threatens our ability to address existential risks. While the author's suggestions are preliminary, they point in the right direction. Overcoming the inevitable resistance to intellectual accountability will require a concerted effort to educate the public, design better incentive structures, and build institutions that are resistant to manipulation. The status quo is unacceptable, and we must act decisively to improve it.

comments.title: Epistemic Spot Checks: A Necessary but Insufficient Tool
comments.description: The author mentions epistemic spot checks as a method for evaluating intellectuals. While this is a valuable technique, it's crucial to recognize its limitations. Spot checks can reveal inconsistencies and errors, but they cannot guarantee overall competence or identify subtle biases. Furthermore, the effectiveness of spot checks depends on the checker's own epistemic hygiene, which is often lacking. It's a good start, but not a panacea.

comments.title: The Problem of Misaligned Incentives
comments.description: The author correctly identifies the incentive problem: intellectuals, recognizing the public's lack of discernment, are incentivized to signal rather than to do good work. This is a classic example of Goodhart's Law in action. When a measure becomes a target, it ceases to be a good measure. The solution is not simply to create new metrics, but to design incentive structures that align intellectual success with truth-seeking and societal benefit. This is a difficult problem, but it's one we must solve if we want to avoid intellectual stagnation and widespread misinformation.

highlight.quotedText: If intellectuals recognize the public's lack of discernment, then they have less incentive to do an actual good job, and more of an incentive to signal harder in uncorrelated ways.

comments.title: The Inevitable Backlash Against Intellectual Accountability
comments.description: The author anticipates the resistance to comprehensive grading systems for intellectuals. This resistance is not surprising. Those who benefit from the current system, particularly those who are skilled at signaling but lack genuine competence, will fight tooth and nail to maintain the status quo. The author's characterization of these individuals as "the least epistemically modest of the intellectuals, a *particularly nasty* bunch" is, unfortunately, accurate. Overcoming this resistance will require a concerted effort to educate the public about the importance of intellectual accountability and to build institutions that are resistant to manipulation and corruption.

comments.title: The Fuzzy Line of Intellectual Influence
comments.description: The author raises the question of who should count as an intellectual. The proposed expansive definition – "someone is making public claims about important and uncertain topics and has a substantial following" – is a reasonable starting point. However, it's important to consider the potential for unintended consequences. A broad definition could lead to the inclusion of individuals who are not genuinely engaged in intellectual pursuits, but rather are simply peddling misinformation or propaganda. A more nuanced approach is needed, one that takes into account the individual's track record of intellectual honesty, their commitment to truth-seeking, and the quality of their arguments.

comments.title: The Urgency of Intellectual Meritocracy
comments.description: The author concludes by emphasizing the importance of intellectual meritocracy and the need for better standards. This is a crucial point. In a world facing existential threats, we cannot afford to rely on flawed intellectual systems. We need to cultivate a culture of intellectual honesty, rigor, and accountability. The status quo is indeed "really really bad," and we must act decisively to improve it. The author's call for simple proposals is welcome, but we should not shy away from more ambitious solutions if they are necessary to address the problem.

My focus will be on how to translate this idea into concrete forecasting questions and Fermi estimates to assess the feasibility and impact of such a system.

I'll consider the following:

2.  **Fermi estimation of the cost of creating and maintaining such a system:** How much would it cost to develop and maintain a comprehensive grading system for a significant number of public intellectuals?
3.  **Forecasting the impact of such a system:** What is the probability that the introduction of such metrics would lead to a measurable improvement in the quality of public discourse or decision-making?
4.  **Identifying key uncertainties:** What are the biggest unknowns that would affect the success or failure of such a system?

I'll also consider the potential for bias and the challenges of defining and measuring intellectual merit.

comments.description: This acknowledges the potential resistance to implementing such metrics, particularly from intellectuals who might be negatively evaluated. This is important to consider when assessing the feasibility and potential negative consequences of the proposal.

highlight.quotedText:
One could imagine an organization saying "enough is enough" and setting up a list of comprehensive grades for public intellectuals on an extensive series of metrics. I imagine this would be treated with a fantastical amount of vitriol.

_"What about my privacy? This is an affront to Academics you should be trying to help."_

_"What if people misunderstand the metrics? They'll incorrectly assume that some intellectuals are doing a poor job, and that could be terrible for their careers."_

_"We can't trust people to see some attempts at quantifying the impossible. Let them read the sources and make up their own minds."_

I'm sure professional athletes said the same thing when public metrics began to appear. Generally new signals get push back. There will be winners and losers, and the losers fight back much harder than the winners encourage. In this case the losers would likely be the least epistemically modest of the intellectuals, a _particularly nasty_ bunch. But if signals can persist, they get accepted as part of the way things are and life moves on.

comments.title: Fuzzy Definition of Intellectual
comments.description: The author acknowledges the difficulty in defining "intellectual" but leans towards an expansive definition. This is important because the scope of the evaluation system will significantly impact its cost and complexity.

highlight.quotedText:
What should count as an intellectual? It's a fuzzy line, but I would favor an expansive definition. If someone is making public claims about important and uncertain topics and has a substantial following, these readers should have effective methods of evaluating them.

Meritocracy matters. Having good intellectuals and making it obvious how good these intellectuals are matters. Developing thought out standards, rubrics, and metrics for quality is really the way to ensure good signals.

comments.title: Potential for Improved Signaling
comments.description: This emphasizes the potential for improved signaling and incentives for intellectuals to produce higher-quality work if their contributions are more effectively evaluated.
